uniting.heading: Climate change is a critical challenge
uniting.text:
Canada's oil sands have a shared goal: net-zero by 2050. But no company can get there alone.
Pathways Alliance is a team-up of Canada's six largest oil sands producers. Our companies make up 95% of Canada's oil sands industry. Together, we can go farther, faster.
We're also working with provincial and federal governments to help Canada meet its Paris Climate Agreement goals. By 2030, our plan could reduce absolute CO₂ emissions from oil sands by 22 million tonnes per year.

directing.heading: A world-class investment
directing.text:
Carbon capture and storage success stories in other parts of the world have shown us what’s possible. Now, Canada’s is increasing our impact.
The Pathways Alliance plan includes investing $16.5 billion in a carbon capture and storage network by 2030. With partnership and co-funding from the Governments of Canada and Alberta, our facility in Western Canada will one of the world’s largest.
That’s just one piece of our plan. Emerging emissions-reduction projects and technologies will receive a $7.6 billion investment. With government and industry united behind cleaner energy initiatives, Canada is proving to be a major player in this important global movement.

capturing.heading: A ready, reliable CO₂ solution
capturing.text:
CCS means carbon capture and storage. It’s a technology that traps, transports and stores industrial CO₂ emissions so they never end up in the atmosphere.
Large-scale projects in Norway and the U.S. have shown that CCS can reduce emissions safely and reliably.
The Pathways CCS project could reduce net CO₂ emissions by 10 to 12 million tonnes per year by 2030, from 14 oil sands production facilities. And that’s only the beginning.
It’s a big step forward on the path to net zero.

transport.heading: A transportation line for the region
transport.text:
Our carbon capture and storage project will serve multiple oil sands facilities, all at once. A transportation line connects each facility to a central storage hub. This line carries captured CO₂ in liquid form to a location where it can be stored underground.
The transportation line is more than 400 km long. In phase one, it will connect 14 oil sands facilities to the storage hub, eventually serving more than 20.
The network isn’t just for the oil sands. In the future, this transportation line can help other industries in the region capture and store CO₂.

storage.heading: A geological vault
storage.text:
Once CO₂ is captured and transported, it’s stored deep underground. Only certain places have the right geological formations for CO₂ storage. The Pathways Alliance storage hub near Cold Lake is ideal.
This location has a deep layer of sandstone. Sandstone is porous, which means it’s full of small spaces, like a sponge. When injected underground in liquid form, CO₂ fills these miniscule spaces in the rock. The layer could eventually store more than 1.1 billion tonnes of CO₂.
Above the sandstone layer lies hundreds of metres of rock salt, which act as a natural seal. Beneath is metamorphic basement rock, which is impermeable (it has no spaces).
Constant monitoring at every depth ensures stored CO₂ remains secure and stable.

innovation.heading: Innovation opens more paths to net zero
innovation.bucket1Text: An alternative fuel source that could reduce the need for natural gas in industrial processes.
innovation.bucket2Text: An alternative, efficient fuel source for mine haul trucks, to reduce their reliance on diesel.
innovation.bucket3Text: A new technology that can remove CO₂ directly from the air, transport it and storeit permanently underground.
innovation.bucket4Text: A low-carbon source of hot water and steam for bitumen production, to reduce natural gas use.
innovation.bucket5Text: A safe, scalable source of zero-emissions energy for applications like heat, steam and electricity.
